title: [K-12] Language-Integrated Instructional Design for Radiation Safety Education: Strengthening Expert Text Expression and Communication Competencies

context.prior_knowledge: Fundamentals of radiation physics, basic principles of medical imaging equipment operation, understanding of specialized terminology in science/medical fields, and foundational text analysis and writing skills
context.additional_context: In a smartphone-based VR simulation-driven practical education environment, learners integrate text analysis/writing/presentation activities related to radiation safety to holistically develop language skills (reading, writing, expression). Emphasizes specialized terminology, logical structuring, and visual aid integration.

learning_goals: Explain and perform patient positioning procedures in a simulated environment with 90% accuracy using radiation safety protocol terminology (e.g., dose, shielding, exposure) in scientific texts.

Use virtual reality simulation tools to express radiation exposure calculation results as graphs/tables/descriptive texts, practice optimization strategies three+ times, and present findings in a logical problem-solution structure.

In a 4-member team-based scenario, learners develop three radiation emergency response procedures in a project format (proposal, PPT), and deliver presentations applying five+ specialized terms and logical expression skills (problem-solution structure, comparative analysis) to meet 4/5+ (80%+) rubric criteria.

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
